p: Over the last several decades, the model of food production embedded in the United States, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand has spread across the world, encompassing countries as varied in their economic and development status as China, Kenya, and Paraguay.3 Here, what is often referred to as “big ag”—including “big meat,” “big dairy,” “big feed,” and the factory farms and feedlots they rely on—has moved from the margins closer to the center of food systems.
